Situation1: A serious situation has come up in the family, and the grandfather's presence is needed.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: A cruising aircraft simply requests the routine altimeter setting.
Story: I sat at my console, headset snug over my ears, eyes flicking between the radar screen and the clock. My shift was steady—just routine traffic, nothing out of the ordinary. Then my phone buzzed. It was my daughter. Her voice trembled as she told me my grandson had fallen and was being rushed to the hospital. “Dad, can you come?” she pleaded. My heart clenched. I was the one they turned to in moments like this, the steady hand, the comforter. But just then, a pilot’s voice crackled through my headset, requesting the altimeter setting. My training kicked in—I knew how vital every instruction was, how a single misstep could ripple into disaster. I glanced at the family photo taped to my monitor, my grandson’s gap-toothed grin beaming back at me. The weight of both worlds pressed down on my shoulders. My family needed me, but so did the pilots in my airspace. I felt torn, the expectations of grandfather and controller pulling me in opposite directions, each demanding my full attention, each impossible to ignore.
